1. If instead of buying a 5-year-old child a physical gift, you contributed $100 to an investment account earning 8% per year for the next 13 years, about how much money would he or she have at 18?
  • $1,300
  • $1,400
  • $2,000
  • $2,600
That's correct.
No.

This is an example of the power of compound interest, which means your money earns interest on interest it has already accrued. Using Grow’s compound interest calculator, you can see that this contribution could turn into $2,300.

2. If you put $1,200 worth of holiday gifts on a credit card with 18% interest in December, how much will you have to pay per month to zero out the balance by the end of 2021?
  • $100
  • $110
  • $150
  • $200
That's correct.
No.
If you had a no-interest credit card, you could pay $100 per month and have it paid off within a year. With an 18% APR, you’d have to pay an extra $10 per month. You can also use Grow’s loan payoff calculator to find out what your monthly payments would be.
3. How much money from your 2020 health-care flexible spending account (FSA) can you roll over into 2021?
  • $250
  • $550
  • $750
  • It depends on your employer
That's correct.
No.
The maximum amount you can roll over into 2021 is $550, but your employer has to opt in for this. Your employer can choose to allow a grace period of 2½ months instead, or do nothing. Be sure to check in on your company’s policy before the year ends.
4. Which of the following can you NOT use money in your health-care FSA to purchase?
  • Bandages
  • Contact lenses
  • Toothpaste
  • Pregnancy test
That's correct.
No.
There are many useful things you can buy if you need to use up your FSA money before the end of the year. Personal care items, like toothpaste, cannot be purchased with FSA funds. The IRS website has a full list of expenses that are included and not included in the FSA program. This year, thanks to the CARES Act, you can use your FSA funds to purchase over-the-counter medication and feminine care products.
5. If you bought shares of a company in January 2019 and sold them for a profit this summer, how much will you owe in federal taxes on the sale if your annual income is $50,000?
  • 15% of the total sale price
  • 15% of the gain, which is the sale price minus the purchase price
  • 22% of the total sale price, based on your income tax bracket
  • 22% of the gain, which is the sale price minus the purchase price, based on your income tax bracket
That's correct.
No.
For any security you hold for more than a year, you pay the long-term capital gains tax rate, which is 15% for most people, on your profit. If you sell a security within a year, it’s considered a short-term capital gain and is taxed as ordinary income.
You got _ out of 5 right.
